PLOT IN A HORROR CAMPAIGN To make a game truly horrifi c, you need more than mood, new rules, or even a truly scary villain. You need a solid plot, one that will engross the players and encourage them to keep going to see what happens next, to really get into character. It can be the same sort of plot you would fi nd in any other fantasy campaign. Dungeon crawls, wilderness exploration, behind-the-lines wartime missions, and political maneuver- ing all have great horror potential. The only true requirement is that the story be solid and believable in the context of the setting: Anything else will make it diffi cult for your players to really feel what their characters are experiencing. Don’t create all your horror stories as mysteries. Mystery and horror fit well together, and horror usually contains elements of the unknown.
